newsitem.title: USA: Missouri planting progresses before rains in week.
newsitem.headline: Missouri planting progresses before rains in week.

text.p: Clear weather before weekend rains allowed cotton and corn planting in Missouri to progress near completion in the week to Sunday, the Missouri Agricultural Statistics Service said in its weekly report.
Corn was 96 percent planted versus 89 last year and 71 on a five-year average, or one month ahead of normal progress.
Cotton planting was 98 percent complete, vs 89 last year and 90 on average, about a week ahead of normal pace.
Single-crop soybeans were 58 percent planted vs 35 a week ago, 3 weeks ahead of last year and 2 weeks ahead of average.
Sorghum was 60 percent planted versus 43 last week, 45 last year and 44 average -- about 10 days ahead of normal.

Condition of winter wheat condition improved slightly at 61 percent rated good to excellent, up one percentage point, and 27 percent rated fair. Heading was virtually complete in the southern third of the state and 71 percent statewide.
Temperatures averaged one to 4 degrees below normal in the week, the agency said.
Topsoil moisture was rated 7 percent surplus, 59 adequate, 31 short and three very short, slightly drier than last week.
Pasture and range condition was rated 3 pct excellent, 41 good, 41 fair, 13 poor and 2 very poor, steady on last week.
